repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Municipal Development in Rural
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Development in Rural Areas
            Project sought to reduce the incidence of poverty in rural
            areas of participating states by: (i) supporting investments
            in basic small-scale social and productive infrastructure,
            utilizing a proven effective community-driven development
            approach; (ii) strengthening municipal administrative and
            technical capacity to increase the efficiency of municipal
            investments; and (iii) deepening the ongoing
            decentralization from Federal to the State and Municipal
            levels. There are two main factors which led to the
            cancellation of the loan: (a) lack of a national project
            coordination unit; and (b) poor state commitment. These
            issues could not be satisfactorily resolved and continued to
            jeopardize the project for almost two years. At the Country
            Portfolio Performance Review discussions in June 2004, it
            was agreed that the Government of Mexico would seek a
            cancellation of the remaining loan.

Mexico - Municipal Development in Rural

TF038493-MEXICO:  MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Municipal Development in Rural
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Development in Rural Areas
            Project aims to reduce the incidence of rural poverty in the
            participating states, by supporting investments in
            small-scale social, and productive infrastructure, through a
            community-driven development approach, and, by strengthening
            municipal, administrative and technical capacity, as well as
            deepening decentralization from the Federal to the State,
            and Municipal levels. The project components are as follows.
            1) Municipal subprojects will provide matching grants to
            rural municipalities, to support demand-driven investments
            in small-scale social, and productive infrastructure, for
            water supply and sanitation, schools construction, health
            centers and community development facilities, waste
            disposal, rural electrification, and road improvements. 2)
            The municipal development and support for decentralization
            component, will offer technical assistance (TA) to
            strengthen the process of decentralization, and build a
            framework to enhance municipal development. Activities shall
            include diagnostic studies of programs, and institutional
            capacities; TA to develop new programs; development of
            monitoring capacities; as well as the establishment of
            coordinating agreements between Federal, State, and
            Municipal entities, including TA to prepare, and amend as
            necessary, the regulatory and legislative framework. 3) The
            incremental costs (excluding salaries) related with project
            supervision, evaluation and monitoring will be financed.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Municipal Development in Rural
            Areas Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This document provides a social
            assessment, and an Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) reflecting
            the socioeconomic conditions of local populations if the
            project's four states. The social assessment depicts an
            existing social participation strategy, with strong emphasis
            on social participation, community and municipal-level
            decision taking. The IPP details characteristics of the
            indigenous population, their social and cultural context,
            and defines ways to strengthen a socio-cultural
            participation strategy, specific for indigenous communities,
            and municipalities. One major finding indicates that
            indigenous communities' access to the benefits of the
            previous Municipal Project, have been more than
            proportional, but there are still demands for more
            information, and training, to improve subproject execution.
            This IPP includes additional training assistance for STU,
            and COPLADEMUN staff; implementation of diagnostic studies,
            and implementation of Municipal Social Plans, as a tool to
            prod economic development among indigenous populations.
            Monitoring and evaluation will be achieved through baseline
            studies, mid-term reviews on social participation
            assessments, and, statistical analysis of investment
            allocations among indigenous, and non-indigenous
            communities, to be encompassed by a final evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Municipal Development in Rural
            Areas : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            potential adverse environmental impacts resulting from the
            implementation of subprojects, and, proposes mitigation
            measures as follows. Regarding water supply subprojects,
            engineering designs will pay particular attention to aquifer
            capacities, limiting as possible the number of aquifers to
            be exploited, while proposed subprojects in the proximity of
            solid waste disposal sites, or industrial areas, or
            agricultural areas with potential chemical, or fertilizer
            residues, shall not be approved. Barriers should be
            installed to protect water sources, and its immediate
            surrounding areas. Water pipes should be sanded as needed in
            an effort to control corrosion, plastic sealed, and,
            inspected on a regular basis. Sewerage subprojects will fall
            under strict regulations regarding the disposal of flammable
            substances, while the use of resistant sewage pipelines will
            be enforced, to control corrosive industrial residues.
            Appropriate natural drainage systems should divert rainfall;
            conversely, wastewater flows, sludge, and sewage will be
            diverted towards large, non-permeable soil areas, to prevent
            aquifers, and/or surface water contamination. Ventilating
            systems should be installed to prevent air pollutants such
            as fuel, and methane gases.

Mexico - Municipal Development in Rural
